verses.text: In the days when the judges ruled, there was a famine in the land. And a man from Bethlehem in Judah went to stay for a while in the fields of Moab, he, his wife, and his two sons.
verses.comment: Bethlehem is literally translated as 'House of Bread'; the mention of famine is significant contextually.

verses.text: The name of the man was Elimelech, the name of his wife Naomi, and the names of his two sons were Mahlon and Chilion, Ephrathites from Bethlehem in Judah. They went into the fields of Moab and stayed there.
verses.comment: Retaining original names and places; 'fields of Moab' refers to the region of Moab.

verses.text: But Elimelech, Naomi’s husband, died, and she was left with her two sons.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'left' is used for the Hebrew 'remained.'

verses.text: And they took for themselves Moabite wives—the name of one was Orpah, and the name of the other Ruth—and they lived there about ten years.
verses.comment: ‘Took for themselves wives’ reflects the Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: Then both Mahlon and Chilion died. Naomi was left without her two children and her husband.
verses.comment: Keeping phrasing close to text. ‘Children’ is modern English; original says ‘sons’.

verses.text: Then she arose with her daughters-in-law to return from the fields of Moab, for she had heard in the fields of Moab that the LORD had visited his people and given them food.
verses.comment: ‘Visited’ is a direct translation; means God helped his people.

verses.text: So she departed from the place where she had been, and her two daughters-in-law went with her. They set out to return to the land of Judah.
verses.comment: Literal translation of movement and destination.

verses.text: And Naomi said to her two daughters-in-law, 'Go, return each of you to your mother’s house. May the LORD deal kindly with you as you have dealt with the dead and with me.'
verses.comment: ‘Deal kindly’ is from Hebrew ‘hesed’ meaning loving-kindness.

verses.text: 'May the LORD grant that you find rest, each of you in the house of her husband.' Then she kissed them, and they raised their voices and wept.
verses.comment: 'Rest' refers to security in a marriage; direct translation.

verses.text: And they said to her, 'No, we will return with you to your people.'
verses.comment: Simple and literal rendering.

verses.text: But Naomi said, 'Turn back, my daughters. Why will you go with me? Do I still have sons in my womb that they may become your husbands?'
verses.comment: 'Sons in my womb' refers to Levirate custom, literal rendering.

verses.text: 'Turn back, my daughters, go your way, for I am too old to have a husband. Even if I thought there was hope for me, even if I had a husband tonight and bore sons,'
verses.comment: Maintains same condition as original text.

verses.text: 'would you wait for them until they were grown? Would you refrain from marrying? No, my daughters, for it grieves me very much for your sakes that the hand of the LORD has gone out against me.'
verses.comment: 'Hand of the LORD' means God's sovereign action.

verses.text: Then they raised their voices and wept again. Orpah kissed her mother-in-law, but Ruth clung to her.
verses.comment: ‘Clung to her’ preserves the Hebrew word ‘dabaq’.

verses.text: And she said, 'Look, your sister-in-law has gone back to her people and to her gods; return after your sister-in-law.'
verses.comment: 'Gods' refers to the Moabite deities.

verses.text: But Ruth said, 'Do not urge me to leave you or to turn back from following you. For where you go, I will go; and where you stay, I will stay. Your people shall be my people, and your God my God.'
verses.comment: Direct quote, keeping poetic form; 'stay' is Hebrew ‘lodge’.

verses.text: 'Where you die, I will die, and there I will be buried. May the LORD deal with me, and worse, if anything but death separates me from you.'
verses.comment: 'Deal with me, and worse' is a Hebrew oath.

verses.text: When Naomi saw that Ruth was determined to go with her, she stopped urging her.
verses.comment: ‘Determined’ translates ‘strengthened herself.’

verses.text: So the two of them journeyed until they came to Bethlehem. When they came to Bethlehem, the whole town was stirred because of them, and the women said, 'Is this Naomi?'
verses.comment: 'Stirred' means surprised, excited.

verses.text: She said to them, 'Do not call me Naomi; call me Mara, for the Almighty has dealt very bitterly with me.'
verses.comment: 'Naomi' means pleasant; 'Mara' means bitter.

verses.text: 'I went away full, and the LORD has brought me back empty. Why call me Naomi, when the LORD has testified against me and the Almighty has brought calamity upon me?'
verses.comment: ‘Testified’ indicates God's judgment.

verses.text: So Naomi returned, and Ruth the Moabite, her daughter-in-law, with her, who came back from the fields of Moab. They came to Bethlehem at the beginning of barley harvest.
verses.comment: ‘Barley harvest’ situates the story in the annual agricultural cycle.
